title: How to Find Edible Plants
content: Look for common edible plants like dandelions, cattails, and clover.

title: Building a Survival Shelter
content: Use branches, leaves, and debris to insulate against cold.

title: Purifying Water
content: Boil water for at least 5 minutes or use a purification tablet.

title: Starting a Fire
content: Use dry tinder, flint, or a magnifying glass to ignite a fire.

title: Starting a Fire
content: Use dry tinder, flint, or a magnifying glass to ignite a fire.

title: Edible Plants
content: Dandelions, cattails, clover, and pine nuts can be safely consumed.

title: Water Purification
content: Boil water for 5 minutes or use purification tablets.

title: Basic Shelter
content: Use branches, leaves, and debris to build an insulated shelter.

title: Starting a Fire
content: Use dry tinder, flint, or a magnifying glass to ignite a fire.

title: Edible Plants in North America
content: Acorns, wild rice, blueberries, dandelion greens, cattails.

title: Natural Water Sources
content: Use maple trees, streams, and rainwater collection.

title: Snow Shelters
content: Use snow caves or igloos in winter survival situations.

title: Firewood Types
content: Oak, hickory, and maple provide long-lasting burns.

title: Edible Plants in South America
content: Coconut, cassava, guava, Brazil nuts, palm hearts.

title: Rainwater Collection
content: Collect rainwater and use bamboo as natural storage.

title: Jungle Lean-To
content: Use raised platforms to protect against floods and insects.

title: Avoiding Jaguars
content: Travel in groups and avoid moving alone at night.

title: Foraging in Europe
content: Hazelnuts, wild garlic, nettles, and chestnuts are safe.

title: Mountain Streams
content: Glacial streams are usually safe but should be boiled.

title: Rock Shelters
content: Use caves or large rock formations for wind protection.

title: Using Flint
content: Flint stones are abundant and work well for fire-starting.

title: Edible Plants in Africa
content: Baobab fruit, wild yams, moringa leaves.

title: Finding Water in Dry Regions
content: Dig near dry riverbeds and collect dew in the morning.

title: Thatch Huts
content: Use grass, palm leaves, and mud for insulation.

title: Avoiding Scorpions
content: Shake out clothes and shoes before wearing.

title: Foraging in Asia
content: Bamboo shoots, lotus root, wild ginger, edible ferns.

title: Using Bamboo
content: Bamboo stores rainwater inside hollow sections.

title: Bamboo Structures
content: Bamboo poles make strong, flexible shelter frames.

title: Avoiding Cobras
content: Stamp feet to warn snakes before stepping into tall grass.

title: Bush Tucker
content: Witchetty grubs, bush tomatoes, and macadamia nuts are edible.

title: Desert Water Sources
content: Dig under dry creek beds for underground water.

title: Desert Shelters
content: Use rock formations for shade and temperature control.

title: Avoiding Spiders
content: Check under logs and inside shoes before putting them on.
